title: Quiz 1: Fundamentals & History of Health Promotion
topicName: Principles & Practice of Health Promotion I
description: Assess your understanding of core definitions, the Ottawa Charter, and historical evolution of health promotion.

questions.question: According to the Ottawa Charter (1986), which of the following is the standard definition of Health Promotion?

options.text: The prevention of disease through medical intervention.
The process of enabling people to increase control over, and to improve, their health.
A state of complete physical, mental and social well-being.
The distribution of health resources to vulnerable populations.

questions.explanation: The Ottawa Charter defines Health Promotion as 'the process of enabling people to increase control over the determinants of health and thereby improve their health'.
questions.hint: Focus on the concept of 'enablement' and 'control'.

questions.question: The Health Promotion Logo established in 1986 contains a red outer circle which symbolizes ___BLANK___.
questions.explanation: The outer circle symbolizes the need for policies to 'hold things together' and the objective of Building Healthy Public Policies.
questions.hint: It represents the overarching framework required to support health actions.

questions.question: Based on the Ottawa Charter, which of the following are part of the five priority action areas? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: The 5 action areas are: Building healthy public policy, Creating supportive environments, Strengthening community action, Developing personal skills, and Re-orienting health services.
questions.hint: Think about the 'wings' of the Health Promotion logo.

questions.question: Match the Health Promotion Core Value with its correct description:

richContent.content: Core Values guide the ethical implementation of health promotion activities.

pairs.right: Enabling people to gain greater control over decisions affecting their health
Taking account of separate influences and their interaction
Ensuring fairness of outcomes for service users
Working in partnership with other relevant agencies

questions.explanation: Empowerment focuses on control; Holistic on the whole picture; Equitable on fairness; Intersectoral on partnerships.
questions.hint: Connect 'fairness' to equity and 'partnerships' to sectors.

questions.question: Which 1974 report is considered the first significant milestone in the 'New Public Health Era', proposing that environment and behavior are more important than biophysical qualities?
questions.explanation: The Lalonde Report (1974) shifted focus from the medical model to lifestyle and environmental factors.
questions.hint: Named after a Canadian Minister of Health.

questions.question: Arrange the following Health Promotion Declarations/Conferences in chronological order (Oldest to Newest):
questions.hint: Alma-Ata was the foundation for 'Health for All'.

questions.question: The 'McKeown Thesis' argued that medical advancements and public health initiatives were the primary causes of improved health standards in the 18th/19th centuries.
questions.explanation: False. Thomas McKeown argued that improvements in economic conditions and standards of living (diet/nutrition) were more important than medical or public health advances.
questions.hint: McKeown questioned the return on investment of the medical model.

questions.question: In the Health Promotion logo, what do the three wings breaking the outer circle represent?

options.text: The three levels of disease prevention
The three basic strategies: Enable, Mediate, Advocate
The five major action areas needing a coordinated approach

questions.explanation: The three wings represent the five major action areas (Ottawa Charter) that need to be addressed in a coordinated way.
questions.hint: The *inner circle* represents the strategies; the wings represent the actions.

questions.question: Which term describes the process of reconciling competing interests in society (e.g., tobacco trade vs. health) to create supportive conditions for health?
questions.explanation: Mediation aims at reconciling competing interests (like economic vs health) to protect the population.
questions.hint: Think of a 'middle man' resolving a conflict.

questions.question: Health is defined not merely as the absence of disease, but as a resource for ___BLANK___.
questions.explanation: The Ottawa Charter emphasizes that health is a resource for everyday life, not the object of living.
questions.hint: It allows you to function daily.
